s.text: Besides explaining why competition and consumer ire aren't slowing the managed-care juggernaut, these findings also suggest that tougher regulations are unlikely to make insurers serve patients better.

Wage and price controls then in effect prevented employers from giving raises, but because the government regarded health insurance as a tax-free benefit, employers used it to fatten compensation packages for workers.

If car insurance were a tax-free benefit, it wouldn't be surprising to find employers picking low-cost insurers who make you visit "preferred" mechanics and skimp on coverage for Land Rovers and minivans.
